title: I Chords
stimulusHtml:
12 Points

This question determines the student’s ability to work with seventh chords, both in root position and inversion, translate chord symbols into actual pitches, approach and resolve the seventh as a dissonance, and to create good horizontal lines. The question also covers the strict resolution of the cadential six-four and the dominant seventh.

Chords (12 points, 2 points per chord)

  1. Award 2 points for each chord that correctly realizes the given chord symbols.

    1. All seventh chords must contain four voices.

    2. All triads must contain at least three voices.

    3. All inverted triads and seventh chords must be complete.

    4. The fifth may be omitted from any root-position chord.

  2. Award 1 point for chords containing the correct chord members but with one of the following errors:

    1. An inappropriate doubling of a chordal seventh or a leading tone.

    2. More than one octave between adjacent upper parts.

  3. Award no points for chords that have more than one error listed in Section I. 2. DO check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

  4. Award no points for incorrectly realized chords. Do NOT check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

    EXCEPTION: DO check the voice leading into and out of chords that are correct except for a missing or incorrect accidental.

Scores with Additional Meaning

0 Response demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

Notes

  1. Do not penalize a response that includes correctly used non-chord tones.

  2. An incorrectly used non-chord tone will be considered a voice-leading error.

Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  1. Parallel (consecutive)—unacceptable.

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  3. Unequal 5ths [d5 —> P5]. In a three- or four-part texture a rising d5 —>P5 is acceptable ONLY in the progression I V43 I6. Otherwise it is unacceptable. (The reverse [P5 —> d5] is acceptable voice leading.)

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

    N.B. Most sources equate “hidden” and “direct.” For purposes of scoring, it seems useful to refine those definitions, particularly in light of past grading practice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the following points.

This question determines the student’s ability to work with seventh chords, both in root position and inversion, translate chord symbols into actual pitches, approach and resolve the seventh as a dissonance, and to create good horizontal lines. The question also covers the strict resolution of the cadential six-four and the dominant seventh.

I. Chords (12 points, 2 points per chord)

  1. Award 2 points for each chord that correctly realizes the given chord symbols.

    1. All seventh chords must contain four voices.

    2. All triads must contain at least three voices.

    3. All inverted triads and seventh chords must be complete.

    4. The fifth may be omitted from any root-position chord.

  2. Award 1 point for chords containing the correct chord members but with one of the following errors:

    1. An inappropriate doubling of a chordal seventh or a leading tone.

    2. More than one octave between adjacent upper parts.

  3. Award no points for chords that have more than one error listed in Section I. 2. DO check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

  4. Award no points for incorrectly realized chords. Do NOT check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

    EXCEPTION: DO check the voice leading into and out of chords that are correct except for a missing or incorrect accidental.

Scores with Additional Meaning

0 Response demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

Notes

  1. Do not penalize a response that includes correctly used non-chord tones.

  2. An incorrectly used non-chord tone will be considered a voice-leading error.

Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  1. Parallel (consecutive)—unacceptable.

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.

Student response earns 2 of the following points.

This question determines the student’s ability to work with seventh chords, both in root position and inversion, translate chord symbols into actual pitches, approach and resolve the seventh as a dissonance, and to create good horizontal lines. The question also covers the strict resolution of the cadential six-four and the dominant seventh.

I. Chords (12 points, 2 points per chord)

  1. Award 2 points for each chord that correctly realizes the given chord symbols.

    1. All seventh chords must contain four voices.

    2. All triads must contain at least three voices.

    3. All inverted triads and seventh chords must be complete.

    4. The fifth may be omitted from any root-position chord.

  2. Award 1 point for chords containing the correct chord members but with one of the following errors:

    2. More than one octave between adjacent upper parts.

  3. Award no points for chords that have more than one error listed in Section I. 2. DO check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

  4. Award no points for incorrectly realized chords. Do NOT check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

    EXCEPTION: DO check the voice leading into and out of chords that are correct except for a missing or incorrect accidental.

II. Voice Leading (12 points, 2 points per connection)

  1. Award 2 points for good voice leading between two correct chords.

    N.B. This includes the voice leading from the given chord to the second chord.

  2. Award only 1 point for voice leading between two correct chords that feature:

    1. Any approach in similar motion to perfect octaves/fifths in the outer voices involving a skip in the soprano voice (hidden or direct octaves/fifths).

    2. Overlapping or crossed voices.

    3. Chordal sevenths that are not prepared by step or common tone unless they are part of a correctly used appoggiatura in the soprano.

  3. Award no points for voice leading between two correctly realized chords if:

    1. Parallel (consecutive) octaves, fifths, or unisons occur, including those by contrary motion.

    2. Uncharacteristic leaps occur (e.g., A2, tritone, or more than a fifth).

    3. The leading tone in an outer voice is unresolved or resolved incorrectly.

    4. Chordal sevenths are unresolved or resolved incorrectly.

    5. One of the chords is a triad with only three voices.

    6. More than one error listed in Section II. 2. occurs.

III. Scores with Additional Meaning

0 Response demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

IV. Notes

  1. Do not penalize a response that includes correctly used non-chord tones.

  2. An incorrectly used non-chord tone will be considered a voice-leading error.

V. Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  1. Parallel (consecutive)—unacceptable.

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

    N.B. Most sources equate “hidden” and “direct.” For purposes of scoring, it seems useful to refine those definitions, particularly in light of past grading practice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.

  3. Unequal 5ths [d5 —> P5]. In a three- or four-part texture a rising d5 —>P5 is acceptable ONLY in the progression I V43 I6. Otherwise it is unacceptable. (The reverse [P5 —> d5] is acceptable voice leading.)

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

    N.B. Most sources equate “hidden” and “direct.” For purposes of scoring, it seems useful to refine those definitions, particularly in light of past grading practice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.

Student response earns 10 of the following points.

This question determines the student’s ability to work with seventh chords, both in root position and inversion, translate chord symbols into actual pitches, approach and resolve the seventh as a dissonance, and to create good horizontal lines. The question also covers the strict resolution of the cadential six-four and the dominant seventh.

I. Chords (12 points, 2 points per chord)

  1. Award 2 points for each chord that correctly realizes the given chord symbols.

    1. All seventh chords must contain four voices.

    2. All triads must contain at least three voices.

    3. All inverted triads and seventh chords must be complete.

    4. The fifth may be omitted from any root-position chord.

  2. Award 1 point for chords containing the correct chord members but with one of the following errors:

    1. An inappropriate doubling of a chordal seventh or a leading tone.

    2. More than one octave between adjacent upper parts.

  3. Award no points for chords that have more than one error listed in Section I. 2. DO check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

  4. Award no points for incorrectly realized chords. Do NOT check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

    EXCEPTION: DO check the voice leading into and out of chords that are correct except for a missing or incorrect accidental.

Scores with Additional Meaning

0 Response demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

Notes

  1. Do not penalize a response that includes correctly used non-chord tones.

  2. An incorrectly used non-chord tone will be considered a voice-leading error.

Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  1. Parallel (consecutive)—unacceptable.

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  3. Unequal 5ths [d5 —> P5]. In a three- or four-part texture a rising d5 —>P5 is acceptable ONLY in the progression I V43 I6. Otherwise it is unacceptable. (The reverse [P5 —> d5] is acceptable voice leading.)

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

    N.B. Most sources equate “hidden” and “direct.” For purposes of scoring, it seems useful to refine those definitions, particularly in light of past grading practice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.

Student response earns 11 of the following points.

This question determines the student’s ability to work with seventh chords, both in root position and inversion, translate chord symbols into actual pitches, approach and resolve the seventh as a dissonance, and to create good horizontal lines. The question also covers the strict resolution of the cadential six-four and the dominant seventh.

    2. All triads must contain at least three voices.

    3. All inverted triads and seventh chords must be complete.

    4. The fifth may be omitted from any root-position chord.

  2. Award 1 point for chords containing the correct chord members but with one of the following errors:

    2. More than one octave between adjacent upper parts.

  3. Award no points for chords that have more than one error listed in Section I. 2. DO check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

  4. Award no points for incorrectly realized chords. Do NOT check the voice leading into and out of these chords.

    EXCEPTION: DO check the voice leading into and out of chords that are correct except for a missing or incorrect accidental.

Scores with Additional Meaning

Notes

  1. Do not penalize a response that includes correctly used non-chord tones.

  2. An incorrectly used non-chord tone will be considered a voice-leading error.

Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  1. Parallel (consecutive)—unacceptable.

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  3. Unequal 5ths [d5 —> P5]. In a three- or four-part texture a rising d5 —>P5 is acceptable ONLY in the progression I V43 I6. Otherwise it is unacceptable. (The reverse [P5 —> d5] is acceptable voice leading.)

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

  6. Direct in outer voices—unacceptable similar motion to a perfect interval that involves a skip in each voice.

    N.B. Most sources equate “hidden” and “direct.” For purposes of scoring, it seems useful to refine those definitions, particularly in light of past grading practice.

  7. Overlapping voices—two adjacent voices move to a position in which the lower voice is higher than the previous note in the higher voice, or they move to a position where the higher voice is lower than the previous note in the lower voice.

  8. Crossed voices—voicing in which the normal relative position of voices is violated, e.g., if the soprano is below the alto, or the bass is above the tenor.

Definitions of Common Voice-Leading Problems

  2. Beat to Beat (perfect intervals on successive strong beats)—unacceptable.

  4. By contrary motion—unacceptable.

  5. Hidden (or covered) in outer voices—acceptable voice leading ONLY when the step is in the upper voice, as shown in Ex. 5; similar motion to a perfect interval that involves one voice moving by step.

title: II Voice Leading
stimulusHtml:
Voice Leading (12 points, 2 points per connection)

  1. Award 2 points for good voice leading between two correct chords.

    N.B. This includes the voice leading from the given chord to the second chord.

  2. Award only 1 point for voice leading between two correct chords that feature:

    1. Any approach in similar motion to perfect octaves/fifths in the outer voices involving a skip in the soprano voice (hidden or direct octaves/fifths).

    2. Overlapping or crossed voices.

    3. Chordal sevenths that are not prepared by step or common tone unless they are part of a correctly used appoggiatura in the soprano.

  3. Award no points for voice leading between two correctly realized chords if:

    1. Parallel (consecutive) octaves, fifths, or unisons occur, including those by contrary motion.

    2. Uncharacteristic leaps occur (e.g., A2, tritone, or more than a fifth).

    3. The leading tone in an outer voice is unresolved or resolved incorrectly.

    4. Chordal sevenths are unresolved or resolved incorrectly.

    5. One of the chords is a triad with only three voices.

    6. More than one error listed in Section II. 2. occurs.
